III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
a. Physical Description of Facility
The Jackson House is located in an older three story home in downtown
Jackson. The house has 4 bedrooms that will hold 12 residents.
Upon entering the front door is an entryway that leads to a hallway with
an open staircase. To the right of the entry way is a living room. To the
left are two offices, one leading to the other.
Past the living room on the left side of the hall is a conference room.
Straight ahead, past the staircase is a rec/computer room. Through the
rec room is a hall leading to a bathroom on the left and a storage room
with fire rated door on the right. Past the storage room on the right is a
mud room/side entry. To the left past the bathroom is a laundry/shower
room.
On the second floor, the staircase has an extended railing to prevent falls
over the open staircase. At the top of the stairs is a hallway. To the right
of the stairs and at the end of the hallway is a bedroom with a single bed.
Across from the stairs are two bedrooms each with 4 beds. Past the two
bedrooms the hallway turns to the right. Down that hallway are the stairs
to the attic which will not be used and the bathroom.
2

To the left of the stairs is a bedroom with 3 beds. Straight ahead and past
the 3 person bedroom is a dining room that passes into a kitchen. The
kitchen has all the required amenities and an emergency exit that leads
out onto a staircase going down to ground level.
There is an attached garage, basement, and an unattached out-building
that will only be utilized for storage.
b. Program Description
The Samaritas Jackson House is a program run by Samaritas Refugee in
Lansing. The facility will be utilized by male’s ages 16-17 who have been
deemed as refugees and are unaccompanied by an adult caretaker. The
agency has been given a federal contract to provide services to these
youth. They are awaiting an approval of their license before the State of
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services will issue them a
contract through Refugee Services.
The services the facility will provide are intended to assist refugee and
immigrant teens with acculturation and independent living preparation. It
is set up to provide the residents with a “community-based, open living
environment where male teens engage in skill building activities as part of
the daily milieu within a positive group of peers with similar goals.” The
facility intends to provide the youth with the skills needed to transition into
independent or semi-independent living once discharged from the facility.
The facility will provide the youth in its care with case management,
housing, counseling, independent living classes, acculturation and
transitional services. It will also provide family reunification services and
assistance in maintaining contact, including visits, with family members.
Volunteer mentors will be provided to help the youth meet their goals.
The facility will seek and coordinate with outside services to provide
educational support, legal services, medical, and dental services.
All youth who wish to utilize the program must meet specific criteria set
forth by the Office of Refugee Resettlement/Division of Children’s
Services (ORR/DCS) and/or the Department of Human Services. Since
The Jackson House is funded by ORR/DCS all youth who participate
must be eligible. Some of those eligibility requirements as stated in the
facility’s Intake Procedures include mild behavior issues, minimal mental
health issues, developmentally appropriate to prepare for independent
living as a next placement, not a risk for becoming absent from
placement, past substance use or experimentation with demonstration of
abstinence or recovery behavior, and youth committed to learning
independent living skills.
3

c. Rule/Statutory Violations
The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that a six month original provisional license for 12 males ages
16-17 be issued.
